Similar situation for me.  net.peerCount will steadily drop over time as, I'm assuming, peers getting banned for either reaching the timeout threshold or giving bad hash info or whatever else is going on from TX spamming and stress testing.

Restarting my node will get me back in sync but I'll need to restart again within an hour.

Running geth 0.9.27 as well here. Restarting often. Sometimes restart gets me back on track (that's been pretty rare lately), sometimes it DLs blocks at a steady pace, but always some number of blocks behind what is posted on stats.ethdev - anywhere from 10 to 150, currently about 30. An sometimes it fails to DL anything at all.

I am way out of my league code-wise here, but I imagine that most of the time, the peers I connect to are in the same state of disarray as I am myself, and their "best block" is way behind the overall network's best block.

I am wondering where geth is trying to get its list of peers from. Are those written into the block-chain? i.e. does it pick the miners of the last X blocks on the chain to become its preferred peers?

There is an issue in the p2p layer that causes many connections to fail.
We are fixing the issue right now and it will be part of the next geth release.

> I am wondering where geth is trying to get its list of peers from. Are those written into the block-chain? i.e. does it pick the miners of the last X blocks on the chain to become its preferred peers?

https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/wiki/Connecting-to-the-network#how-peers-are-found
@fjl has this been implemented yet? I assume #1338 is related.
@simondlr The issue that I mentioned was unrelated to #1338 and has been resolved in https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/1212.
